 Babrak Karmal, the Parcham leader, would only be Vice-President, and later, for a few months, Ambassador in Prague. This shows the irreconcilability of the Afghans: once an enemy, always an enemy until death... as we were to see.
It is clear that these first two paragraphs of your excerpt concern two Marxist factions, the Parcham and the Khalq. There is also mention that the leaders of these factions went on to become president and vice-president. It appears to me that this opening to your excerpt is especially meant to support the claim that the communist party was elected. You counter by saying that the excerpt was meant to show your mistake, though you neglected to note at the time a mistake had even been made.
 
 Moving on, let's look now at the more pertinent part of your excerpt:
 
 
The new Constitution was accepted by the Constituent Assembly and he was elected, in March 1977, as President of the Republic for a term of six years.
What's remarkable here of course is the author's contention that Mohammad Daoud Khan was elected as president. Did you pause to consider by exactly what process Daoud was elected? Did you corroborate the author's opinion with an independent reference on Afghan history, or was Reshtya's personal assessment simply accepted at face value? Indeed, since it seems from your URL that the quote is a translation of the original text, one may wonder if the word 'elected' is even Reshtya's own choice.
 
 
It does indicate that there has been at least one election in Afghanistan previous to the one just held which was the main point.
Or perhaps it indicates that with a keyword search you found an article that mentions 'elected' and 'president' in the same sentence. A keyword search is fine for starters, though if you had made some further effort to verify the opinion that Daoud was elected, you might have quickly learned that it in no way resembled the Afghan general election held last Saturday. Your attempt to liken the two events shows how seriously you have misconstrued the meaning of the word election as used in your excerpt.
 
 Just about every media source has characterized the recent presidential election as the first-ever in Afghan history. That alone should have prompted you to question your conclusion that you had uncovered another 'election' that the international media had overlooked.
 
 So what the real story with Daoud and what sort of election transpired in 1977? Prince Daoud was cousin to the king and took power in 1973 in a nearly bloodless coup while the king was in Italy for medical treatment. He purged the military and established his own political party, the National Revolutionary Party, which became the focus of all political activity. He drew up a constitution that would establish a one-party system of government. Resistance to his regime was suppressed.
 
 Those were the circumstances that existed in Afghanistan when Daoud was elected in 1977. You say your main point was to show that at least one election had been held in Afghanistan prior to the one just held. Yet in truth there has never before been a general election where millions of Afghans could vote. 
 
 The process that elected Daoud in 1977 involved no political parties, nor any formal vote. It is what the Afghans call a loya jirga--literally, a 'grand council'. Such councils have been a feature of Afghan society for centuries. To call a loya jirga an 'election' is to use the term very loosely. Besides, there have been more than a dozen loya jirgas in the last century alone. Indeed, several important ones have been organized just since the Taliban were ousted from power.
 
 In my view, there's no equality to your argument. On the one hand you have a 1977 council meeting of less than 400 hundred attendees who, without voting, endorsed Daoud as president of a one-party system of government. While on the other hand you have last week's presidential election in which millions of men and women cast ballots after a period of campaigning by multiple political parties. If you don't see there's a substantive difference between a loya jirga and a nationwide general election, then so be it. What's important is that the Afghan people know the difference, and last week they overwhelmingly embraced it.
 
 One last point, since a loya jirga is how you meant to show that there has been at least one prior election, it's seems odd that you go back to an obscure 1977 meeting that predates the Soviet invasion. Why not simply point to the current era? After all, in June 2002 a loya jirga with roughly 2000 delegates was held in a large tent on the grounds of Kabul Polytechnic University. At that session, Hamid Karzai was named as President for a two-year term, and the transitional government was formed that took office soon afterwards.
